stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes a rare “giant coin” secret collectible (imported from Mario Odyssey with a CPU-driven material look) and integrates it into RTYI’s progression/speedrun economy. He also implements and debugs the Pandora’s Box quest actor (dialogue, cutscene timing, and a ‘storm of ghosts’ visual) while fighting tooling issues (Fast64/Nova64 export path problems) and gameplay bugs (Dorrie transport logic, emulator-specific RNG issues). The stream ends with a major progress update: the first demo is complete and the first chunk of the overworld is functionally finished, but testing is constrained by leak fears.
stream_context.significance_reason: Kaze states the first demo is finished and he’s finished the first part/first third tier of the overworld’s required programming, shifting next toward building the next overworld segment and organizing secure playtesting.

findings.summary: Kaze adds a new ultra-rare ‘giant coin’ collectible intended only for super-hidden Easter egg locations; most players should finish without ever seeing one, and that is intentional.

The giant coin awards roughly 500 coins and permanently saves as collected (one-time pickup via a save flag), but it will not be hinted at, will not have a unique reward, and will not count toward 100% completion.

Primary rationale for giant coins is to improve replayability/speedrunning: Kaze wants speedruns/progression routes to ‘farm Easter eggs/secret areas’ rather than grind regular coins, after noticing coin-farming friction when he assembled and playtested the first third of the overworld.

The giant coin is a 1:1 import of the Mario Odyssey coin model; Kaze recreated its look via a CPU-driven material approach (he calls it ‘kind of a shader’), including normal and roughness maps, and confirmed it runs fine on real N64 without framerate collapse.

Pandora’s Box is designed as a quest/trigger object: first interaction speaks to the player; second interaction ‘kills’ the box, sets a save flag, and causes enemy spawns (the ‘booblas’) to appear in Overworld 3 areas.

Kaze decides Pandora’s Box opening should be presented as a cutscene with subsequent text; he drafts the tone as mocking/mischievous ghosts (‘you fool’) rather than an angry scolding, including adding a ghost-laugh cue to sell the sarcasm.
findings.quote: They’re like, you fool… it’s like, oh no, you ruined your life.

findings.summary: For the Pandora’s Box ‘storm of ghosts’ effect, Kaze prototypes a rotating, scaling visual using scrolling textures on planes; issues encountered include z-fighting, visibility/brightness tuning (primitive color influence), late spawn timing, and needing a larger culling radius.

Engine/pipeline pitfall revealed: when spawning an object, graphics state isn’t fully reset; if a behavior doesn’t assign its own shadow scale, it can inherit a ‘leaked’ shadow from a prior actor occupying the same slot/spot, producing incorrect shadows.

Tooling issue: Fast64/Nova64 exports a wrong file path (missing relative path handling), causing build/compile problems unless Kaze exports twice and/or manually fixes paths; Kaze suspects his decomp repo/build setup hasn’t been updated/configured correctly and notes the issue has existed since around August.
Kaze notices what seems like a minor memory leak while playtesting Overworld 1; he’s confident it’s fixable but flags it as a real issue to revisit.
Kaze states he has finished the entirety of the first RTYI demo and is now looking for a tester to play through it end-to-end before proceeding.

Kaze refuses to send the ROM over the internet for testing because there is ‘too much content’ and he’s worried about leaks; for at least one key area (Overworld 1), he says testing would require an in-person visitor in the Halifax region.

Progress update: Kaze says the first part of the overworld/‘first third tier’ has no remaining required programming tasks, and later clarifies that the first four overworld parts are completely finished (with 12 more still needed overall).
Gameplay tweak: Kaze ‘nerfed the umbrellas’ so they no longer behave wildly when jumped on.

Overworld traversal bug: Dorrie (the transport) can get stuck; Kaze debugs and fixes turning behavior, discovering the logic breaks when the goal is behind Dorrie due to a speed multiplier/turning rule.

biobak.summary: Kaze notes the project should remain under a 64MB cartridge limit ‘even with Biobak saving anything,’ emphasizing that ROM space pressure is dominated by audio rather than graphics assets.

badub.summary: Badub briefly appears in chat (resub); no new music implementation details are discussed in this stream.

zeina.summary: Kaze runs into a Blender workflow problem traced to Zeina’s file settings (‘auto-merge by distance’ unexpectedly enabled), which prevented him from closing/adjusting Pandora’s Box until he disabled it.
Zeina provides a ghost texture for the Pandora’s Box ‘ghost storm’ cutscene effect; Kaze attempts to modify it in GIMP to better match his intended mischievous look and readability in-game.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: As soon as they go after RTYI, I am free. I can turn this into my own game and sell it.
memorable_quotes.context: Said while discussing Nintendo/DMCA risk; reveals a contingency plan and frames legal pressure as a potential ‘escape hatch’ into an original commercial title.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I really want to prevent speedruns from farming coins.
memorable_quotes.context: Explains why the giant 500-coin Easter egg collectibles exist: to reshape replay routes away from repetitive coin grinding.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Speedrunning is essentially like a replay experience, right? And I do care about replayability, so by thinking about replayers I believe I am also thinking a lot about speedrunners.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear statement of how he values speedrunners as a design input without designing only for them.

key_stories.title: The giant Odyssey coin as a hidden economy for replayability
key_stories.summary: Kaze imports the Mario Odyssey coin and rebuilds its look for N64 performance, then reframes it as an ultra-rare, one-time collectible worth ~500 coins. He explicitly wants most players never to find it and for it to exist outside completion metrics.
key_stories.challenge: During assembly/playtests of the first third of the overworld, Kaze realized players (and especially speedrunners) could be forced into boring coin-farming to meet progression needs.
key_stories.process: He prototypes a ‘giant coin’ that persists via save flags, places it only in deep Easter egg zones, and positions it as an optional route optimization: hunt secrets instead of grinding currency.
key_stories.outcome: A new replay/speedrun-friendly progression tool is defined: rare, unhinted, non-100% collectibles that permanently boost the player’s coin total.
key_stories.key_quote: I really want to prevent speedruns from farming coins.

key_stories.title: Pandora’s Box quest object becomes a cutscene with a ‘ghost storm’
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements Pandora’s Box as a two-stage interaction that culminates in the box ‘dying,’ setting a save flag, and unleashing ghosts/related spawns in the overworld. He iterates on a visual effect of rotating, scaling ghost textures and on the tone of the dialogue to feel mocking rather than angry.
key_stories.challenge: He needed a clear, readable signal that the player triggered a lasting world-state change, plus an appealing N64-feasible visual for ‘a storm of ghosts.’
key_stories.process: He prototypes the effect with scrolling textures, adjusts culling radius/shadows, tunes brightness via primitive color influence, and adds audio/text timing (ghost laugh + ‘you fool’ style line) to sell the intended tone.
key_stories.outcome: The effect and event sequence are working in principle, with parameter tuning ongoing (timing, size, readability), and the quest flow (talk → destroy → save flag) established.
key_stories.key_quote: Okay, this has to be a cutscene and then after the cutscene there is a text.

key_stories.title: Finishing the first demo—but playtesting is constrained by leak risk
key_stories.summary: Kaze announces the entire first RTYI demo is finished and he wants a tester to play it through. However, he refuses to distribute ROMs online due to the amount of unreleased content and instead considers in-person testing locally (Halifax region) for at least some material.
key_stories.challenge: He needs real external feedback and validation on the demo’s full playthrough, but distributing builds increases the chance of leaks.
key_stories.process: He searches for a tester and sketches a geographic/in-person solution instead of sending the ROM, implying a need for controlled access to builds.
key_stories.outcome: Demo completion becomes a new production bottleneck: secure testing logistics.
key_stories.key_quote: I need someone to actually come to my house to play it, because I don't want to send the ROM to anyone over the internet.

open_questions.topic: Secure playtesting pipeline for RTYI builds
open_questions.context: Kaze says the first demo is complete and he needs a tester, but he also says he won’t send ROMs online and may require in-person testing in Halifax due to leak risk.
questions: What content specifically makes a remote build ‘too risky’ right now (unfinished worlds, secret tech, story beats, assets)?
Has RTYI experienced leaks before, or is this a preventative policy based on other projects’ experiences?
What would a secure remote testing approach look like for you (NDA, time-limited builds, watermarks, per-tester builds, partial-content slices)?
Which parts of the demo could safely be shared digitally, and which must remain in-person only?
Who ultimately tested the first demo, and what were the most important changes that came from that playtest?

open_questions.topic: Giant coin integration rules and progression math
open_questions.context: Giant coins award ~500 coins and save permanently, are unhinted, and are not part of 100% completion; Kaze’s goal is reducing coin grinding and improving speedrun routes.
questions: How many giant coins do you expect to ship in the full game, and what’s your target ‘discovery rate’ (e.g., 10% of players find 1)?
How do you balance coin requirements so normal players never need to grind, but secret-hunters can still feel rewarded?
How are these ‘one-time’ collectibles tracked technically (save flags per coin vs a global bitset, per-overworld vs per-level)?
Will you communicate anywhere (manual, optional NPC, postgame stats) that ‘secret economy’ items exist, or is it purely for community discovery?
Are giant coins meant to influence any progression gates, or only serve as a convenience buffer?

open_questions.context: Kaze says ‘I’m not a writer’ while drafting Pandora’s Box dialogue and tone, and he’s deciding how much intro dialogue the star/quest needs.
questions: Who, if anyone, is responsible for writing/voice/tone across RTYI—does the team have a process for it?
What is the intended player takeaway from Pandora’s Box (warning about curiosity, comedic guilt, foreshadowing, lore)?
How many times will the box address the player, and will the dialogue evolve if the player revisits the area later?
How do you decide when an interaction needs a cutscene versus in-game text only, especially given pacing in hub worlds?

open_questions.topic: Fast64/Nova64 export path issue and repo divergence
open_questions.context: Kaze reports an export bug where tools write files to a subfolder but the build expects them in the main folder; he suspects missing ‘relative path’ support/config in his decomp and says he’s had the issue since ~August.
questions: What specific version(s) of Fast64/Nova64 and the SM64 decomp are you on when this breaks?
Did you choose not to update your decomp for stability reasons, or did the break happen after an update?
What is the exact workaround you use now (export twice, manual move, script), and how much time does it cost per iteration?
Is this issue affecting other team members’ workflows (artists exporting assets), and did it force any pipeline conventions?

open_questions.topic: Emulator accuracy policy for development and for players
open_questions.context: Kaze suspects a Dorrie bug was due to Project64 not emulating the count register correctly, breaking his random function’s low bits; he switches to a ‘good emulator’ for verification.
questions: Which emulators and hardware do you officially test against, and what is your ‘minimum bar’ for claiming compatibility?
Have you implemented any mitigations for emulator timing/RNG differences (e.g., avoid count-register dependence, add deterministic RNG options)?
Will RTYI communicate recommended emulators (or discourage Project64) to players/speedrunners?
How often do emulator-specific bugs masquerade as game bugs in your workflow, and how do you triage them quickly?
